Fields.DialogueText: Welcome aboard, Cap!
Thank you, Texas! It's great to finally meet you. Your reputation precedes you.
Now whatd'ya mean by that?
Oh, well you are one of the more experienced Belles in the fleet, so I--
Experienced? Ya callin' me old, Cap!?
What? No! Of course not!
Easy, Bluebonnet, I was just joshin'! It's true I ain't no greenhorn. This ain't my first war neither.
Well, we're happy to have you around. The other Belles really look up to you. You and your... steed.
Aw shucks, Cap! I can't see why they'd do that. It's all in a day's work for me an' Bluebonnet.

Fields.MenuText: You've already accomplished so much during your service.
Well, you did fight for the Atlantic Fleet during the Great War.
Not every Belle can say they were the flagship for an entire fleet.

Fields.DialogueText: Now there you go callin' me old again!
I miss all those convoy runs on the North Sea. Can't say I miss the cold much, though. Would've appreciated the horse keepin' me warm.
Bein' a flagship's overrated, Cap. It's too noisy and it's too crowded.
I've lost track of all the refits and retrofits, but I'll tell ya what - I never ran into a problem a couple o' big guns couldn't solve.
*ALARM*
Looks like we've got Morganas off the port bow. Care to show me those guns of yours in action?
Por supuesto, Capitán!
@BATTLE
*METALLIC WHICKER*
*ROBOT WHINNY*
Oh, there you are, Texas! I still haven't had a chance to compliment you on that fight against the Morganas the other day. I was impressed by how fast you fired off your first salvo.
I've been teachin' the gunnery officer to be quicker on the draw. You don't gotta overthink things. If you see banditos on the horizon, then just start shootin'.
Hmm… that explains why the guns fired before I gave the order.
You'd rather be the one done shot at first?
Well no, but on a ship, the guns shouldn't fire unless they receive orders.
With all due respect, Cap, that's not how we do things in Texas.
I'll keep that in mind…
I've noticed you like to spend most of your time out here on the deck.
I like to ride herd on things. Gotta be out here to do that.

Fields.MenuText: I like to keep an eye on things too. That's why I spend so much time on the bridge.
It's nice to come out on the deck and get some fresh air once in a while.
Keeping an eye out for Morganas?

Fields.DialogueText: Runnin' a ship's more than just starin' at charts and chattin' on the radio, cooped up on the bridge all day.
I ain't out here relaxin'. I'm out here workin', Cap!
Yep, and that ain't all.
There's a lot to do 'round here. You've gotta see what's what out here on the deck, talk to your sailors 'round the galley, and stick yer head in the engine room every now and then.
Those things are important, but there's so much traffic coming in from HQ lately. I need to be on the bridge to make sure we react fast enough. The Morganas can be so unpredictable.
I gotcha. We Belles can tell when things ain't quite right, though. Me an' Bluebonnet get a better sense of that out here than we do up on the bridge.
*ALARM*
That must be the Morganas again! I'm heading back to the bridge.
“Dispara y después pregunta,” Cap! “Shoot first, ask questions later!”
@BATTLE
And anyway, Bluebonnet's always chompin' at the bit to whip those painted rowboats one. Everyone wins.
*ACKNOWLEDGING SNORT*
*MARTIAL WHINNY*
Howdy, Cap!
Ah, there you are. Greetings, Texas!
That ain't whatcha supposed to say, Cap! If we're gonna work together, we need to be a little less formal. You can say howdy back, or just smile and nod, tip yer hat…
*SPLASH*
Was that a shell landing in the water?
Yep.
Morganas, half the distance to the horizon!
Commence firing, Texas!
Aye-aye, Cap!
@BATTLE
These banditos sure are persistent.

Fields.MenuText: You took care of them pretty easily.
I wonder how they snuck up on us like that...
That was a close one!

Fields.DialogueText: I just wish they'd get the message and quit comin' back.
I'm not sure. Usually the radios start actin' up before they get that close.
Close only counts in horseshoes, Cap. They're sunk and we ain't, so that's all that matters.
We'll have to keep our guard up to avoid being ambushed like that again. The Morganas are always interfering with our electronics, so we can never tell if they're coming or going.
You said it, amigo. If you're out on the range and something spooks the herd, you can bet that trouble's on the way.
Right… but we need to figure out a way to protect our electronics from the Morgana interference. It's not like we've got a herd of cattle on the deck.
Huh. Now, that's not a bad idea, Cap! Maybe I can pick up a few longhorns next time we're in port. They can help us stand watch.
You can't be serious.
Bovine detection and ranging, Cap! I call it BODAR.
Catchy.
Just you wait, Cap. It'll be everywhere before this thing's done!
You're tellin' me! Bluebonnet always gets a little staticky when they come creepin'.
*SNORT* *BUZZ* *PAW* *PAW*
*CREAK*
Texas! I wasn't expecting to find you here in the engine room.
The heck you walkin' in here for, Cap?
I'm following your advice, actually. You suggested getting off the bridge and spending more time talking to sailors in other parts of the ship.
Huh. Well, I guess I did say that, didn't I?
Yes, you did. What are you doing down here in the engine room?
Ah, you caught me red-handed, Cap! Since you're new on board, I'm fixin' to welcome you with a good ol' fashioned Texas barbecue!
Why thank you! I do appreciate your hospitality... but are you cooking in the engine room?
I'm just trying to figure out a way to cook you some barbacoa. I need a good source of heat, and it seems like these boilers'll do the trick.
Barbacoa? What's that?
It's an old Tejano recipe. Done right, you dig a hole in the ground, put a cow's head down in there, throw on some agave leaves, and cook it overnight until the meat's all tender.
You cook a cow's head underground for an entire evening… and then what do you do after that?
What kinda question's that, Cap? You dig it up and you eat it, of course!

Fields.MenuText: That sounds delicious!
Well, that sounds… unique.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course it is, Cap! We're not the most patient people in Texas, but we do know you've gotta wait for good barbecue.
Ain't nothing like the food in Texas, Cap!
I can tell you're a little apprehensive, Cap, but trust me. You'll thank me after you take your first bite.
Anyhoo, we can't dig a pit on the ship to do this the 100% authentic way, so the next best thing is steamin' the meat on top of this here boiler.
*ALARM*
Morganas again!
Might as well get a fight in while we're waiting, Cap. This barbacoa needs another few hours anyway.
@BATTLE
*THUD*
Here's your barbacoa, Cap! That's genuine Tejano barbeque for ya!
I wasn't expecting the meat to still be on the cow's head - and for the cow to still be… looking at me.
Cap, what kinda city slicker are ya? Beef comes from cows, whether ya like it or not. Now let me help you out. All you need is a tortilla, some of this salsa verde…
I have to admit, it does smell delicious.
The rest of y'all sailors feel free to dig in too! I made it to welcome the Captain on board, but there's more than enough to go around.

Fields.MenuText: You're quite generous, Texas. Thank you!
We've been at sea for a while now, so I'm sure the sailors appreciate a little change of pace in the galley.
Wow, this salsa is spicy!

Fields.DialogueText: No problem, Cap. Glad to have a captain like you in command.
You've gotta take care of the crew, Cap. Without sailors, this ship would just be a floatin' museum piece.
Really? I tried to go light on the chilis for ya, Cap.
Thank you so much for the meal. You really didn't have to go through all this trouble. I can't believe I ate so much. The meat was so juicy and full of flavor, and the tortillas so soft...
It's just common courtesy to welcome you with some good eats! Maybe the barbacoa was a little exotic to start with, though, so I'll fix up something a little simpler next time.
I'm so stuffed! I really can't think about any more food right now.
Maybe some brisket, ribs, and sausage… Oh! Gotta snag some rivets for Bluebonnet.
*ALARM*
Morganas again! Cap, you need some help gettin' out of yer chair?
No… I'm okay… it was just a lot… of barbacoa.
We're waiting on you, Cap! But I'll go ahead and get the guns ready.
@BATTLE
Rivets? Not... I don't know, oats?
He ain't built like a regular horse. A healthy bucket of bolts perks him right up, don't it, Bluebonnet?
*APPROVING PURR*
What'd ya call me up here for, Cap?
We just received a communiqué from HQ. Come take a look at this chart. The Morganas are massing a small fleet around this area.
That's not too far away, ain't it?
Exactly, so HQ wants us to intercept them somewhere around these islands over here.
The fastest way would be to sail right at 'em, but if we come around this other direction here, we can come in behind 'em and herd the whole dang fleet into that bay yonder.

Fields.MenuText: That's a great plan! We'll catch those Morganas totally off guard!
Do you think we're fast enough to sail around them like that?
Why don't we take a more direct route?

Fields.DialogueText: Sometimes it's better to finesse things a bit, Cap.
We'll have to sail at full speed to catch 'em, but we'll have 'em rounded up 'fore they know what's what.
I don't recommend it, Cap. These Morganas have been gettin' tougher every time we see 'em.
All right, we'll go with your plan then.
You ever hear of a Comanche Moon, Cap? The Comanche scheduled raids right after sunset on a full moon. They caught their enemies off guard and still had enough light to see.
Point is, you gotta make sure ya tip all the odds in yer favor.
Understood. I wonder if the Morganas even sleep at night though… and I heard they might be able to see in the dark…
I've heard a lotta things about those brujas, Cap. Silver bullets usually do the trick with witches and such, so I'm fixin' to melt down some fancy silver I found in the wardroom.
What? That silver is government property, Texas! You can't just melt it down!
We all gotta make some sacrifices for the war. You'll thank me later when you see how those silver bullets work against the Morganas.
Well, that's IF the bullets work against the Morganas.
Worst case scenario is they still get shot, Cap.
Worst case scenario is that silver comes out of your stipend.
*ALARM*
Morganas again!
We'll have to continue this discussion later.
@BATTLE
Hell, I can't take it with me. Silver's for spendin' or shootin', and I don't see a casino out here.
The Morganas are straight ahead. We expect to make contact soon.
Sounds great, Cap!
With this plan of yours, we should be able to push the Morgana fleet into that harbor for a decisive engagement.
It'll be as simple as shootin' fish in a barrel.
Let's hope so. What are you snacking on there?
Fritos, Cap.
Fritos?
Yep. There's a company in Texas that makes these. They're fried corn chips. Muy delicioso! Here, try one...
Mmm… crunchy… tasty! Reminds me of potato chips!
Better than potato chips, Cap! I think they'll really catch on with people.
Hmm… I could see that happening. Anyway, I came out here to tell you to get ready for the Morganas.

Fields.MenuText: Did you manage to track down enough silver for those bullets you're making?
If we're going to herd these Morganas, we need to hit them hard!
Did you ever get that BODAR system set up?

Fields.DialogueText: Naw, there wasn't enough silver in the wardroom. Now I'm asking around with the crew, but for some reason it seems like no one wants to part with whatever silver they've got.
That's not how you move a herd, Cap. You've gotta give just enough pressure to start movin' 'em, then let up a bit so they don't just bolt.
Now what kinda silly question is that? We've been at sea for weeks. How am I supposed to rustle up a herd of cows in the middle of the ocean?
I see. Well, we'll have to ready all the weapons we have on hand and hope that they'll be enough to get the job done.
I got a good feeling about it, Cap! I just oiled the horse this morning.
@BATTLE
*SNORT* *NOD*
Looks like we hit that Morgana fleet just hard enough to get them moving!
Just like we planned, Cap! Now all we gotta do is drop back and tail 'em for a bit, and give 'em a nudge every now and then to keep 'em sailing in the right direction.
It'll take a while to push them over into that bay, but once we've got them trapped in there, we can really pummel them with all we've got.
We're a good team, Cap. Things are always easier when you've got a good partner.
Agreed! We're like that radio show - the one with the Texas ranger that wears a mask and fights for justice.
The Lone Ranger?
Yes, that's the one! The Lone Ranger and his trusty sidekick, Tonto.
I've seen a few of the serials. It's always a good time seein' those Hollywood types tryin' to play cowboy. What's that line of his again?
“Hi-yo Silver, away!”
Ha! That's right. No Texas Ranger in their right mind would ever be that flamboyant.
Haha, don't worry, Texas. I suppose that's my line anyway.
… You sayin' I'm Tonto, Cap?

Fields.MenuText: It's only natural. I am the ship's captain, after all.
I didn't mean it so literally. I just meant we're a good team, like the Lone Ranger and Tonto.
Well, I suppose if anyone has to be the Ranger, it would have to be you.

Fields.DialogueText: You're a great captain, but I think I got you beat on using a lasso and workin' a six-shooter.
Suppose you wouldn't look too bad in a mask and cowboy hat, Cap!
Just givin' you a hard time, Cap! The important thing is we both wanna bring those banditos to justice!
Anyway, do you know what Tonto actually means in Spanish?
*ALARM*
We can pick this up later. Looks like the Morganas need another nudge in the right direction! Ándale, Bluebonnet!
@BATTLE
We've got those Morganas moving again. Just a little bit further and we'll push them into that bay like we planned.
Looks like it, Cap.
You've got your guitar out at a time like this?
I ain't too worried about those Morganas. We haven't had too much trouble with 'em so far. Besides, it's always good to wind down a bit after a long ride.
I suppose so. That last battle was pretty intense, though.
Aw Cap, ya shouldn't get too worked up about fightin'. Fightin's what we're here for, so it's all in a day's work.
I'm glad you can keep up such a positive attitude. It helps motivate the crew. What was that song you were singing when I walked up?
Oh, that one? That was just a little ditty I wrote about the Tampico Affair.
Ah, that was when you occupied Veracruz before the start of the Great War.
We weren't occupyin', Cap! We were just showin' 'em who's boss. It's called diplomacy. Sometimes you can get what you want if you just let 'em know you mean business.

Fields.MenuText: It's always better to solve problems without fighting.
I'm not sure if diplomacy will work against the Morganas.
I didn't know you were a musician too. You're really talented, Texas!

Fields.DialogueText: Of course it is, Cap. It's easier to do yer convincin' when you've got the bigger gun, though.
It hasn't so far. But diplomacy ain't never gonna work unless you've got a threat to back it up. So if they wanna fight, that's what we'll give 'em.
Aw, I wouldn't say I'm a musician, Cap. I just know how to strum enough cowboy chords to sing my songs by the campfire.
Well, it is nice to hear some music around here, between all the shouting and guns firing.
I like to write songs about the things I've seen. I ain't playin' Carnegie Hall anytime soon, but I'm happy to play for you and the crew.
Ah, Carnegie Hall! New York is your sister, isn't she?
Yep! We're as different as night and day, but I love the heck out of her!
*ALARM*
Looks like those Morganas are getting close again!
We'll show 'em a little more of our “diplomacy,” Cap!
@BATTLE
We've managed to trap their whole fleet in the bay!
Looks like those banditos got nowhere to run now.
Your plan really worked, Texas! This will be a huge win for us when we take out so many Morganas at once.
We've got a great captain and the best crew in the fleet, Cap. I wouldn't expect any less.
I'll give the command to commence fire once all our ships are in position.
We'll come at 'em with all guns a-blazin'. This shootout won't last too long.
What's that you've got in your hand?
Managed to find enough silver to melt down for a few silver bullets, Cap!

Fields.MenuText: Where did you find the extra silver you needed?
Do you think you'll be able to get close enough to use those?
I hope they work against the Morganas.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, I found a few odds and ends in your quarters. Just some decorative things on the shelf that were catchin' dust. Figured I could make 'em a little more useful.
We've already got 'em trapped in the harbor. If we have to form a boarding party, I wanna make sure I've got the crew's back.
They're definitely witches, Cap. Only thing I'm wondering now is how pure that extra silver was that I found on the shelf in your quarters.
What can I say? You're full of surprises, Texas.
You gotta be resourceful if you're riding out on the frontier. Ain't nobody gonna help ya but yerself.
Well, I'm happy we've got a full crew with us today, Texas. The ships are in position. Let's commence fire.
Aye-aye, Cap! We'll give 'em hell!
@BATTLE
Besides, if they don't work, a chunk of silver's like a sugar cube to good old Bluebonnet.
*SWIVEL*
See? Perks his ears right up.
Great job, Texas! Looks like we got them all!
Those Morganas are done for for now, but I wouldn't be surprised if they came back. They never seem to be sunk for too long.
I'm sorry you never had a chance to test out your silver bullets.
Aw, no problem, Cap. There's always next time. But I do think the silver will keep 'em dead… at least a little longer.
I'm not sure how these things work exactly, but you seem to know a bit more than I do.
I know about brujas and banditos, Cap. I'm not too sure what the heck these Morganas are, though.

Fields.MenuText: They seem like witches to me.
They're bandits on the high seas!
We'll need a more thorough scientific investigation to be certain.

Fields.DialogueText: We'll know for sure once I get a chance to use these silver bullets.
Ha! Well, the Lone Ranger takes care of bandits with silver bullets too.
If you wanna be scientific about it, I've got six bullets right here. Put me in front of a Morgana, and I'll do some hypothesis testin'.
Well, I'm sure it won't be too long before we see Morganas again.
Hope things calm down for a bit, because I'm working on another barbecue to celebrate our first big victory together.
More barbacoa? I was so stuffed after that last big barbecue.
Hope you worked up an appetite, Cap. I'm cookin' up the Holy Trinity of Texas barbecue this time - brisket, ribs, and sausage.
Will there be any vegetables involved?
Well, you got yer choice of peach cobbler or pecan pie.
Those aren't vegetables.
What d'ya mean? Oh, I suppose we'll have some corn and frijoles too--
*ALARM*
Seems like we didn't quite finish off those Morganas.
Always got to mop up the stragglers, Cap! Glad I still got my boots on.
@BATTLE
Texas, that's the biggest group of Morganas I've ever seen.
Yep.
It looks like we weren't the ones doing the herding. The Morganas lured us right into their trap.
Looks like it.
We sank a few Morganas in the harbor, but they drew us into an ambush. We're seriously outnumbered by all the Morganas out there!
I believe the technical term fer what's out there is an “armada,” Cap.
I don't think we stand a chance against them.
Ain't no shame in buyin' some time while we radio HQ and hold out for the cavalry to get here.

Fields.MenuText: We need to sail out of this harbor right now before we're the ones getting trapped.
If we stand our ground and fight, I don't think we can last long enough for help to arrive.
Maybe with a little luck, we can win!

Fields.DialogueText: Pronto, Cap!
Agree with you Cap. We need to get movin' 'fore we end up on the Morgana dinner table.
I admire the optimism, Cap, and I ain't one to back down from a fight, but the numbers ain't good. We should sail out of here until we can get more guns on our side.
Let's set course for open water, and radio HQ to send more ships our way.
Aye-aye, Cap.
*BOOM*
Seems like we're gonna have to fight our way out of this one.
It's a situation you're used to by now, I'm sure.
Ha! Got that right, Cap!
@BATTLE
*INQUISITIVE NICKER*
It's an expression, hon.
*CREAK*
There you are, Texas. I'm assuming you're not cooking barbecue down here again.
Naw, Cap. There's time for that later, but if we're goin' to outrun this Morgana armada that's nippin' at our heels, we've gotta get all we can out of these engines.
Thanks for the help, Texas.
No problemo, Cap. Just got these new oil-fired boilers a few years ago. They're a little finicky sometimes, but a heck of a lot better than my old coal boilers.
The Dust Bowl's got nothin' on shovelin' coal in the engine room when yer runnin' full speed ahead.
I'm glad we were able to break through that Morgana blockade, but HQ says it'll take almost a full day for reinforcements to join us.
With these engines, we can keep up full speed as long as we've got enough oil.

Fields.MenuText: We've got plenty of fuel on board, so no need to worry about that.
I don't think Texas will run out of oil anytime soon.
Can you get us sailing any faster? I think the Morganas are catching up.

Fields.DialogueText: A good captain always plans ahead for situations like this!
Ya got that right, Cap!
I'm givin' her all she's got, Cap!
Some of the smaller ships in that Morgana armada are faster than us, so we won't be able to outrun them completely.
They can try to ride us all they want, but this bronco can buck.
*BOOM*
I think that's your cue, Texas.
Time to get up on deck and rope those dogies!
@BATTLE
We're managing to pull away from their main fleet, but their faster ships keep catching up with us.
We'll have to keep sailing and keep swattin' away those flies until we meet up with the reinforcements.
Right. Speaking of which, we've got Moranas approaching off the stern. They're closing in fast.
I'm on it, Cap. It's a perfect chance for me to finally test out these silver bullets!
@BATTLE
Nice shooting, Texas! Hopefully those Morganas won't be back for a while.
Yep! Those silver bullets worked like a charm, too!

Fields.MenuText: Those Morganas started taking on water the second you hit them with those silver bullets!
I guess it was worth the sacrifice of the wardroom silver.
It was hard to tell. The main guns and torpedos took them out pretty fast.

Fields.DialogueText: You noticed that too, huh? I think I'm on to something here with these brujas...
We'll be dining at the bottom of the ocean unless we get rid of these Morganas.
Come on, Cap! You've gotta pay closer attention to the details.
In any case, we'll meet up with the reinforcements in a few hours.
I can't wait to finally turn around and blast these Morganas right out of the water!
Come look at this chart. We'll link up with the rest of our fleet on the other side of this island chain, so it's not much further.
That's good news, Cap. Runnin' ain't really my style!
We're gettin' pretty close to the shoreline, Cap.
This is the fastest route we could take to link up with our fleet.
I don't like huggin' the coast like this. It makes me a little anxious. I like bein' out over open water - got more room to breathe out there.
Don't worry. Once we've got a few more ships on our side, we can take the fight back to that Morgana armada.
Shallow water makes me nervous, Cap. I'm only admitting this to ya because we've gotten to know each other a bit, but I ran aground once.
You ran aground? That… that doesn't seem like you at all.
It's a long story, and not my proudest moment. I was visiting my sister in New York…
It was during the Great War… there were hundreds - no, THOUSANDS of mines at the mouth of Long Island Sound…
It was a pitch black night, darker than Texas tar, and the shore lights - those lights were a-shinin' off the water…
I couldn't tell north from south, took a wrong turn, and WHAM! Stuck on a sandbar. Can you imagine that?

Fields.MenuText: Everyone makes mistakes, Texas. Don't be too hard on yourself.
I'm sure anyone would have had trouble getting out of the sound in those conditions.
That must have been really embarrassing! A battleship running aground in its own harbor?

Fields.DialogueText: It was the most embarrassing moment of my life.
Well, sure anyone would have had trouble, Cap. But people expect a little more from Texas...
Well yeah. You don't have to rub it in, Cap.
I was stuck there for three days until the tugs could pull me free. After that, I had to turn right around and head back to the yard to get my hull fixed!
You know what it's like for a Texan to be stuck in New York City for that long?
Probably more painful than taking a barrage of Morgana gunfire.
Ha! That's a different kind of pain, Cap.
*ALARM*
The Morganas are getting a little too close again.
I'm on it, Cap!
@BATTLE
We made contact with the other fleet, and are coordinating a link-up on the other side of the next island.
Combined, we should have enough firepower to take on the Morgana armada.
I can't wait, Cap. I'm tired of runnin'. Time for the Lone Ranger and Tonto to rope us up a few banditos.
That's right, Texas! Then you'll finally be able to cook up that victory barbecue that you've been planning.
Well, we're running a little low on all the ingredients I need, so I hope we can get back to port to resupply soon.

Fields.MenuText: Don't worry, Texas. Once we get reinforcements, that Morgana armada won't stand a chance. We'll get back to port after that.
You could change the menu. We don't have to do barbecue this time.
We can always make do with some of the canned food we have in storage.

Fields.DialogueText: I love being out on the water, Cap, but there's nothing to do but catch fish out here. That's all right for a little while, but you can't have a barbecue without brisket and ribs.
Hmm… good point. But we're all out of cheese and sour cream, and I don't think I've ever seen any masa harina or avocados on board.
Cap, I'm just gonna forget you said that.
Let's focus on planning how to take out these Morganas. Then we can get back to figuring out the menu.
Plannin' for the Morganas is easy, Cap. We just bring bigger guns than the ones they've got. Now tell me, how I'm supposed to make tortillas without cornmeal?
*ALARM*
Can't you just use regular flour?
Aw, they're not as good like that, Cap!
@BATTLE
We're getting heavy radio interference from the Morganas. All we can hear is static. We've lost contact with the other fleet, and our navigation equipment has gone haywire.
At least we can still see the shoreline, Cap. We can hug the coast and meet up with the fleet where we were supposed to.
Yes, that's the best thing to do for now. Don't worry, Texas - we'll be on the lookout for sandbars.
Now I never shoulda told ya that story about runnin' aground in New York, Cap! I'll never live that one down.

Fields.MenuText: You have to admit, it is a funny story. You were stuck on sandbar for three whole days!
I heard it was mostly the navigator's fault anyway, so you shouldn't feel responsible.
It happened a long time ago now. I'm sure no one remembers it.

Fields.DialogueText: You know what that does to a Belle's pride? Gettin' roped up by a bunch of tugboats, and bein' too big and heavy to budge?
Cap, now you know better than me that a captain's responsible for everything on board. I blame myself though - maybe I was in too much of a hurry to get out of there.
There ya go callin' me old again! I'll never forget it, even if no one else remembers.
Well, the important thing is to learn from our mistakes.
Like they say, Cap. "Those who don't learn history are doomed to repeat it."
Anyway, I really don't like losing our radios and navigation at a time like this. The crew is tired, and we can't afford to slip up with that Morgana armada behind us.
Speak of the devil - there's some more Morganas closing in fast! Good eye, Bluebonnet!
@BATTLE
You're tellin' me. The horse's been feelin' magnetic all the live-long day.
*CRACKLE* *NEIGH*
First the electronics went out, and now we're surrounded by this mist from the Morganas! I'm not sure if we're still on course...
I don't like this at all, Cap. This is just like New York all over again, 'cept we've got a Morgana armada on our back.
We can barely make out the shoreline…
*BOOM*
Heck of a time for the Morganas to attack!
It doesn't look like too many of them, so let's engage. We can figure out where we're going after they're gone.
I'll get the guns firing, but keep an eye on the helm! We're in shallow water, Cap! Bluebonnet, knees high!
@BATTLE
Nice shooting, Texas!
I had to take 'em out quick, so we could get back to navigatin'.

Fields.MenuText: All of our systems are still out from the Morgana interference. We still have no idea how far off course we are.
No visibility… no navigation equipment… no radio...
You might be able to make out the shoreline through all this mist - if you look hard enough?

Fields.DialogueText: I reckon we're not too far off course, but let's take it slow and get our bearings.
Cap, now's not a time to start feelin' sorry fer yourself! We need a plan.
It's no use with all this mist, Cap.
Let's drop anchor here. I'm okay with no visibility or no electronics, but losing both at the same time is too dangerous in these waters.
I don't like droppin' anchor anywhere, Cap. But looks like we ain't got any better options right now.
I know you don't like sitting still, Texas, but we've got to be prudent.
*ELECTRIC WHINNY*
Just keep an eye out. Bluebonnet's liable to chew through the anchor chain if he gets too bored.
*DEFENSIVE SNORT*
Looks like we made a bad decision, Cap.
I didn't know what to expect when the mists cleared up, but I wasn't expecting to find ourselves trapped in a harbor, surrounded by the entire Morgana armada.
Well… at least we didn't hit a sandbar.
That's true.
Yep.
So… it looks like we're in a bit of trouble.
Aw, Cap, this ain't nothin' our guns can't fix.

Fields.MenuText: Our radios are still out, so we can't even call for help.
It's the same Morgana fleet we've been running from for days. What makes you think we can beat them now?
It was a pleasure serving with you, Texas.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, that just simplifies the decision makin' process, Cap. If help ain't comin', the only option's ta shoot our way outta here.
They can outnumber us, Cap, but the better shot always wins.
Cap, I'm gonna hit ya upside the head if you talk like that with the crew around. The only ones dyin' around here are gonna be the Morganas.
You're right, Texas! We've got a good ship, and a great crew. So let's give those Morganas hell!
Now you're talkin' like a Texan, Cap! Let's get this rodeo started!
@BATTLE
*WHINNY* *SUPPRESSING FIRE*
I can't believe you took out so many Morganas in that last battle, Texas!
Well, if they come straight at me broadside like that, they're gonna get some holes blown in their hulls right quick.
They did get surprisingly close though. We took a bit of damage too.
It's all part of fightin', Cap. Ya might have to take a few jabs 'fore you land that cross for the knockout.
True, but did you know that you're on fire?
Huh? Oh, yeah, I guess I am... I'll put it out if it bugs ya.
We're still not out of this yet, so we need to conserve our resources and limit our damage while we figure our way out.
After that last battle, there's a weak spot in the Morgana line. We can break through that blockade if we concentrate our fire.

Fields.MenuText: It's the best plan we've got.
We can't sit here forever, and we might as well keep up our momentum.
Hmm… maybe. Any other ideas?

Fields.DialogueText: It's the ONLY plan we've got.
Now that's the right attitude, Cap!
The only other idea is sittin' here and gettin' shot at, Cap. I can't say I endorse that one.
All right, let's break through that line then. Concentrate fire on those Morganas over there!
Aye-aye, Cap!
@BATTLE
Well, we sank a lot of Morganas, but there are just too many of them. We can't break through their barricade. A lot of our ships took damage too.
We'll need to bring all of our ships in close. We can protect the damaged ones in the rear, with our most fit ships up front.
We have no idea if our reinforcements know where we are or know we need help, but all we can do is hold out for as long as possible… and hope we can eventually break those Morganas.
… I don't like this one bit, Cap.
I don't either, Texas. But we're surrounded, so the only thing we can do is hold on for as long as we can.
You familiar with the Alamo, Cap?

Fields.MenuText: The battle in the Texas Revolution?
I've never heard of the Alamo before.
Oh, you mean the 13-day siege on a group of Texian and Tejano rebels holed up in a poorly fortified mission?

Fields.DialogueText: Yep. A group of Texans holed up in the Alamo for 13 days 'fore Santa Anna's army broke through their defenses.
It was during the Texas Revolution, Cap. Some Texans got themselves surrounded by the Mexican army, and holed up in an old mission called the Alamo. It was 13 days 'fore the battle was over.
You sure know your history, Cap. Seems like history is repeatin' itself right here.
So you're saying this situation we're in is a lot like the Alamo?
Yep.
Well, we'll fight to victory like those brave Texans!
They all died, Cap.
What do you mean?
Well, the Texans lost at the Alamo. Santa Anna killed every last one of them. They all died.
Why are Texans so proud about the Alamo, then?
We're proud of how the Texans fought, Cap. And it motivated all the other Texans to fight even harder for what they believed in.
I promise this won't be our Alamo, Texas. We'll get out of this one together.
Aw, yer right, Cap. Sorry I was bein' negative. We've still got a lot of fight left in us!
We are surrounded, but let's fire a few salvos at those Morganas so they know what we've got waiting for them!
Ha! I like your thinkin', Cap!
@BATTLE
*ARTILLERY WHINNY*
We've got a few Morganas approaching. Their main fleet isn't moving, but it looks like they're probing us to find a weak spot.
We ain't got a weak spot, aside from the fact that we're completely surrounded. We've got the damaged ships in the center, but we've circled the wagons the best we can.
All we can do is wait. We're still trying to get the radio back up, but it's static as usual.
We can just pick 'em off one by one if they're too afraid to come at us all at once.
Got any silver bullets left? There are a couple of Morganas closing in.
I got my gun right here, Cap!
@BATTLE
They were pretty strong, but we managed to sink them!
Why are you holding your head, Texas? Did you take any damage in that last fight?
Ah, I don't know what it is, Cap… but I do know that it's Sabotage.
Sabotage? What do you mean?
Sabotage - the Morgana that was leadin' that there armada. She's Sabotage, Cap.

Fields.MenuText: It doesn't matter who she is - we'll sink her entire fleet to the bottom of the ocean!
Strange how you Belles can pick up on these things...
That's good to know. Thanks for the intel report - it should be useful in the next battle.

Fields.DialogueText: You got that right, Cap!
I don't know why, but we just know things about the Morganas sometimes...
She's a strong one, Cap, so we've gotta watch ourselves out there.
Those Morganas are getting close...
We'll give 'em a warm Texas welcome, Cap!
*CONCERNED LICK*
They're done with scouting out our lines. That whole armada is coming straight at us!
We've done all we could to prepare, Cap. We've got nowhere to run, but there's a whole line of guns pointed straight at those Morganas.
I saw you were just inspecting the guns. How are they looking?
The magazines still have plenty of ammunition, Cap. All the guns are fully operational, and I personally briefed all the gunner's mates on the plan.
What about the firefighting crews? I know that a few small fires don't bother you, but we might be taking a lot of damage. I don't want any fires to get out of control.
Firefightin' crews briefed and on standby, Cap. I also ran through the whole casualty drill in case there's any wounded.

Fields.MenuText: You've trained the crews well, Texas!
Now's our chance to show those Morganas how strong the Neutrality Fleet is!
Looks like we're as prepared as we can be. I'm proud to fight with you, Texas!

Fields.DialogueText: Just doin' my job, Cap.
We ain't gotta prove anything to 'em. We just got to beat 'em.
Proud to have you as my captain!
Looks like those Morganas are finally in range. Commence firing, Texas!
@BATTLE
Commence firing, Bluebonnet!
*EXPLOSIVE NEIGHING*
The Morganas are retreating!
We got 'em to turn tail, Cap!
We're still surrounded with nowhere to go, though. How is the ship?
We took some damage, but we're still floatin'.
It's only a matter of time before the Morganas regroup and mount another attack. How's the crew?
A few minor casualties, but luckily nothin' too serious.
Ammunition status?
We fought 'em off, but we had to fire everything we had nonstop. Can't say we've got enough ammo left to do that too many more times, though. We damn near ran Bluebonnet dry.

Fields.MenuText: Texas, whatever happens, we'll be remembered for fighting bravely.
Let's try and conserve ammunition. We need to make every shot count.
Exactly how many more times can we handle?

Fields.DialogueText: This ain't gonna be another Alamo, Cap!
Cap, if we stop shootin' even for a second, those banditos will drill more holes in us than a Beaumont oil field!
I ain't got the time to do all the math, Cap! We just need to finish these Morganas right quick!
You're right, Texas. Let's give those Morganas everything we've got.
*BOOM*
The Morganas are back again. Return fire!
Aye-aye, Cap!
@BATTLE
*PERSEVERANT SNORT*
We managed to beat those Morganas back again, but it looks like they're already regrouping for another attack.
Third time's a charm, Cap.
What's our status?
We're beat up pretty bad, Cap - and really low on ammo. We've got fires burning on the bow and on the stern. I'm not sure how much more of this we can take.
*BOOM*
Then we'll have to put everything into this last push. From the looks of it, the Morganas are giving it everything they've got too.
Aye, Cap. Here they come again!
You know, you still owe me that barbecue, Texas.
We still need to figure out who's the Lone Ranger and who's Tonto too.
Well, we can talk more after the battle. It'll be a damn good one, so you can bet you'll have another song to write after this.
*BOOM* *PAWING DECK*
Enough talkin' fer now, Cap. Let's rope up those Morganas and bring 'em to justice!
@BATTLE
We did it, Texas! We sunk Sabotage and her whole armada!
Oh Cap, that was a close one, wasn't it? But you know what? During that whole battle, I had this strange feeling whenever I was around you - a rush of heat and a thumpin' in my chest!

Fields.MenuText: That's because we're such good partners, Texas! Like the Lone Ranger and Tonto. There's no bandit that we can't beat together!
Really? I've had the same feeling… a feeling like I'm tired of sailing alone.

Fields.DialogueText: Ha! You got that right, Cap! We're ridin' together for justice, and these ain't the last banditos to catch!
I love the freedom out on the open range, Cap, but I'm tired of ridin' all by my lonesome. I could use your company by the campfire...
Captain! Our radios are back up, and we've made contact with the rest of the fleet!
Tell them to stand by. We need a few minutes to sort things out here.
Texas, care to join me for a walk around the ship to assess the battle damage?
Why thank you kindly, Cap. I don't mind if I do...
*STATIC NUDGE*
Now, don't be ugly, Bluebonnet. There's always room around the fire for you.
